title: prime-seq

source.description: Add cells or tissue to wells

source.body:
Cells
Minimum: 100 cells, Optimum: 10,000 cells
Make sure that the same number of cells are used for each sample. Large differences between cells will impact distribution of sequencing reads and can potentially affect normalization.

Tissue
If samples are difficult to lyse they should be homogenized using a tissue homogenizer.
Tissue should be a relatively small and not exceed more than 1000 ng of RNA. Tissue samples should be normalized by weight and be the same type of tissue.
Large differences between tissue samples will impact distribution of sequencing reads and can potentially affect normalization.
If you are unsure if the samples will contain the same amount of RNA, it is best to switch to the "Lysate (variable)" case in Step 13.

source.body:
Adjust the number of cycles based on input (sample number, cell number, or concentration).
As a rule of thumb we assume big cells like embryonic stem cells to contain 10 pg of total RNA and small cells like T-cells ~ 1-2 pg
As a general guide we recommend:
AB

350 ng14
4100 ng12
5500 ng10
61000 ng9

source.description:
Elute cDNA in
UltraPure Water
Quantify the cDNA using the Quant-iT PicoGreen dsDNA assay kit or equivalent Qubit following the manufacturer's protocol. Use 1 μl of clean cDNA for quantification.
Quality check the cDNA using the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer with High Sensitivity DNA Analysis Kits.

source.body: Passing the cDNA quality check does not guarantee that the data will be of high quality, however, if the cDNA fails the quality check it will usually not yield good libraries and will therefore generate lower quality data.

source.description:

AB
1Reagent1x
2Ultra II FS Reaction Buffer1.4 µL
3Ultra II FS Enzyme Mix0.4 µL
4cDNA (4-8 ng/µL)2.5 µL
5TE1.7 µL
6Total6 µL

AB
1Reagent1x
2Ultra II FS Reaction Buffer1.4 µL
3Ultra II FS Enzyme Mix0.4 µL
4cDNA (4-8 ng/µL)2.5 µL
5TE1.7 µL
6Total6 µL

source.body: Ensure that the Ultra II FS Reaction Buffer is completely thawed. If a precipitate is seen in the buffer, pipette up and down several times to break it up, and quickly vortex to mix. Place on ice until use.
Vortex the Ultra II FS Enzyme Mix for 5-8 seconds prior to use for optimal performance.

source.body: We use SPRI Select Beads here instead of our home made 22% Clean Up beads for their guaranteed QCed size selection properties.

Elute in

Quantify and quality control the library using the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer with High Sensitivity DNA Analysis Kits.

source.body: Bulk libraries often yield high concentrations, which should be diluted to get accurate molarity measurements on the Bioanalyzer. Ideally, do not load more than 2 ng onto the chip.
Successful libraries will typically be 2-5 ng/μl concentration

source.description:
Samples should be submitted according to your Sequencing Facility specifications. At least 8 cycles are required for the Index Read (i7) and 28 cycles for the Read 1 (BC+UMI). Read 2 (DNA) should be adjusted based on the quality of the genome being mapped to, but for human and mouse 50 cycles is sufficient.
Some potential sequencing options:
ABCDEF
1ReadRead 1Read 2Index Read (i7)Index Read (i5)Kit
2HiSeq2811480HiSeq 3000/4000 150 cycles
3NextSeq285680NextSeq 500/550 HiOut v3 75 cycle
4NovaSeq289488NovaSeq SP v1.5 100 cycle

ABCDEF
1ReadRead 1Read 2Index Read (i7)Index Read (i5)Kit
2HiSeq2811480HiSeq 3000/4000 150 cycles
3NextSeq285680NextSeq 500/550 HiOut v3 75 cycle
4NovaSeq289488NovaSeq SP v1.5 100 cycle

Vortex the Fragmentation Mix for
and immediately proceed to step 70

Incubate the Fragmentation reaction as follows:

2Pre-Cool4 C∞
3Fragmentation37 C5 min
4A Tailing and Phosphorylation65 C30 min
5Storage4 C∞

3Fragmentation37 C5 min

source.body: Although scaled down, there will not be sufficient Q5 Master Mix (M0544L) in the kit. This item will have to be ordered separately.
Instead of the universal P5NEXTPT5 primer, one can use unique i5 Indices for each sample. This is recommended if using a sequencer with patterned flow cells to account for index hopping.

source.description: prime-seq can be used on lysate or extracted RNA. It is essential, however, that the samples either have the same input or that they are normalized after the RNA is extracted, otherwise sequencing depth per sample will be impacted. Based on your starting material, please follow one of the following cases:

cases.title: Lysate (similar input)
cases.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4drs3","text":"Follow this case if you are testing samples that have similar input (i.e. the expected RNA amount is the same between samples). The steps here will guide you in digesting residual proteins in your samples, extracting the RNA, digesting DNA, preparing RNA-seq libraries, and finally sequencing. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":53,"length":15,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3khbd","text":"\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"19esn","text":"Example: investigating the genotype effect on transcription in 5,000 neurons","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

cases.title: Lysate (variable input)
cases.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"e2tfn","text":"Follow this case if you are testing tissue that is of variable type or size (i.e. the RNA concentration between the samples will be different). The steps here will guide you in extracting the RNA, digesting DNA, normalizing your samples, preparing RNA-seq libraries, and finally sequencing. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":54,"length":21,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6127c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dg2ed","text":"Example: investigating the genotype effect on transcription in the brain, heart, and spleen. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

cases.title: Extracted RNA
cases.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"79ish","text":"Follow this case if you are testing samples that have already been RNA extracted using a kit, were DNase treated, and have been normalized to the same input. The step here will guide you in preparing RNA-seq libraries and sequencing.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":67,"length":13,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cs1e6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cnhe7","text":"Example: investigating the genotype effect on transcription in 10 ng of RNA from the cortex","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

source.body:
The 4 µL of water can be combined with the Reverse Transcription Mix by increasing the water in Row 6 from 2.35 µL to 6.35 µL.
If working with many samples, or if using a stepper pipette or robot, we find that it is better to add some water separately to prevent the beads from drying too much.

source.description: Weigh the tissue and add to tube.

source.description: Quantify the cDNA using the Quant-iT PicoGreen dsDNA assay kit or equivalent Qubit following the manufacturer's protocol. Use 1 μl of clean cDNA for quantification.
Quality check the cDNA using the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer with High Sensitivity DNA Analysis Kits.

source.body: Passing the cDNA quality check does not guarantee that the data will be of high quality, however, if the cDNA fails the quality check it will usually not yield good libraries and will therefore generate lower quality data.
Before starting, read the library preparation section carefully as there are a few steps that are very time sensitive.

source.description: Quantify and quality control the library using the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer with High Sensitivity DNA Analysis Kits.

source.body: Bulk libraries often yield high concentrations, which should be diluted to get accurate molarity measurements on the Bioanalyzer. Ideally, do not load more than 2 ng onto the chip.
Successful libraries will typically exceed 3-5 ng/μl concentration

source.description:
Samples should be submitted according to your Sequencing Facility specifications. At least 8 cycles are required for the Index Read (i7) and 28 cycles for the Read 1 (BC+UMI). Read 2 (DNA) should be adjusted based on the quality of the genome being mapped to, but for human and mouse 50 cycles is sufficient.
Some potential sequencing options:
ABCDEF
1ReadRead 1Read 2Index Read (i7)Index Read (i5)Kit
2HiSeq2811480HiSeq 3000/4000 150 cycles
3NextSeq285680NextSeq 500/550 HiOut v3 75 cycle
4NovaSeq289488NovaSeq SP v1.5 100 cycle

ABCDEF

3NextSeq285680NextSeq 500/550 HiOut v3 75 cycle
4NovaSeq289488NovaSeq SP v1.5 100 cycle
Homogenize the tissue, while making sure to keep the samples cold

source.body: We have successfully used the Qiagen Tissue Lyzer, at 50 oscillation for 2 min for tougher tissue and 30 oscillation for 2 min for softer tissue.

source.body:
The 4 µL of water can be combined with the Reverse Transcription Mix by increasing the water in Row 6 from 2.35 µL to 6.35 µL.
If working with many samples, or if using a stepper pipette or robot, we find that it is better to add some water separately to prevent the beads from drying too much.

materials.name: Deoxynucleotide Solution Mix - 40 umol of each
Maxima H Minus Reverse Transcriptase (200 U/uL)
NEBNext Ultra II FS DNA Library Prep with Sample Purification Beads - 24 rxns
NEBNext Ultra II FS DNA Library Prep Kit for Illumina

description: prime-seq is a simple and open RNA-seq method, which can be easily established in most research labs or facilities. Based on two of the most sensitive single cell RNA-seq methods available, namely smart-seq2 and mcSCRB-seq (Picelli et al. 2013; Bagnoli et al. 2018), prime-seq is an adaptable, affordable, robust, and high-throughput option. Additionally, prime-seq can be used on a wide range of model organisms, from apes to zebrafish, and many in between.
